(1) This Order may be called the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It shall come into force at once and shall be deemed to have taken effect on the 26th day of March, 1971.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Order, “existing law” means any Act, Ordinance, Regulation, Rule, Order or bye-law which immediately before the 26th day of March, 1971, had the force of law in whole or any part of the territories now comprised in the People's Republic of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. As from the 26th day of March, 1971, all “existing laws” shall, until repealed or altered or amended by competent Legislature or other competent authority, in their application to Bangladesh, be subject to the Adaptation directed in this Order.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. Where an existing law, other than the Income-Tax Act, 1922, the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, the Business Profits Tax Act, 1947, the Estate Duty Act, 1950, the Sales Tax Act, 1951, the Gift Tax Act, 1963 and the Wealth Tax Act, 1963, contains any provision extending the law to the whole of Pakistan or to whole of East Pakistan, that provision shall be so construed as to refer to the whole of the People's Republic of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. References in any existing law, other than the Income-Tax Act, 1922, the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, the Business Profits Tax Act, 1947, the Estate Duty Act, 1950, the Sales Tax Act, 1951, the Gift Tax Act, 1963 and the Wealth Tax Act, 1963, to ‘Pakistan' or ‘East Pakistan' shall, except where the reference occurs in a title 1[ * * *] or any citation or description of an Act, Ordinance or Regulation and except where context otherwise requires, be replaced by references to Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. References in any existing law to ‘Pakistan', ‘Bengal', ‘East Bengal' or ‘East Pakistan' in a title 2[ * * *] or any citation or description in any Act, Ordinance or Regulation shall, except where the context otherwise requires, shall be omitted.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3[ 7. (1) Unless the context otherwise requires-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        any reference in any law for the time being in force, to the High Court, the High Court of Dacca or the High Court of Bangladesh, exercising original, appellate, revisional or other jurisdiction, shall, as from the 16th day of December, 1972, be construed as reference to the High Court Division of the Supreme Court of Bangladesh established under the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) any reference in any existing law to the Supreme Court exercising original, appellate or revisional or other jurisdiction shall, as from the 16th day of December, 1972, be construed as reference to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of Bangladesh established under the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Except as otherwise provided in sub-clauses (a) and (b) of clause 1 and where the context so requires, any reference in any law for the time being in force to the Supreme Court or to the High Court of Dacca or the High Court of Bangladesh shall, as from the 16th day of December, 1972, shall be construed as reference to the Supreme Court of Bangladesh established under the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Any reference in any law to an Advocate entitled to practise before the High Court, shall, as from the 16th day of December, 1972, be construed as an Advocate entitled to practise before the Appellate Division and the High Court Division of the Supreme Court of Bangladesh established under the Constitution.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. Any reference in any existing law to “the Central Government”, “the Government of Pakistan”, “the Provincial Government” or “the Government of East Pakistan” shall be construed as a reference to the Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. Any reference in any existing law to the President of Pakistan, the President, the Governor of East Pakistan or the Governor shall, except where the context otherwise requires, be replaced by reference to Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. Any Court, Tribunal or Authority required or empowered to enforce an existing law shall, notwithstanding that this Order makes no provision or insufficient provision for adaptation of the law for the purpose of rendering it consistent with the Proclamation of Independence or the Provisional Constitution of Bangladesh Order, 1972, construed the law with such adaptations as are necessary for the said purpose:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that if any question arises regarding the adaptation with which such laws should be construed for the said purpose, the question shall be referred to the Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh and the decision of the Government on any such matter shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4[ 11. (1) Any reference in any existing law to the “Advocate General” shall be construed as a reference to the “Attorney General”.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Any reference in any existing law to “Government Pleader” shall be construed as referring to an “Advocate”, or where appropriate, “the Deputy Attorney General (Civil)”, appointed by the Government.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 The words “or Preamble” were omitted by Article 2 of the Bangladesh Adaptation of Existing Laws (Amendment) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 150 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words “or Preamble” were omitted by Article 2 of the Bangladesh Adaptation of Existing Laws (Amendment) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 150 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 Article 7 was substituted by Article 3 of the Bangladesh Adaptation of Existing Laws (Amendment) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 150 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 Article 11 was inserted by Article 4 of the Bangladesh Adaptation of Existing Laws (Amendment) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 150 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
377	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH (ADAPTATION OF INSURANCE ACT) ORDER 1972 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>THE </strong><strong>BANGLADESH</strong><strong> (ADAPTATION OF INSURANCE ACT) ORDER 1972 </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(PRESIDENT'S ORDER NO. 19 OF 1972).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to adapt the Insurance Act 1938 (Act IV of 1938), in its application to Bangladesh; NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of Independence of Bangladesh, read with the Provisional Constitution of Bangladesh Order, 1972, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make the following Order:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Order may be called the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Insurance Act) Order, 1972.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force at once and shall be deemed to have taken effect on the 16th day of December, 1971.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The Insurance Act 1938 (Act IV of 1938), hereinafter referred to as the said Act, shall, until repealed, altered or amended by the Legislature of Bangladesh or by any other competent authority, be subject to the adaptation specified in the following Articles.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. In the said Act, reference to “Central Government” or “Provincial Government” shall, except where the context otherwise requires, be construed as reference to “Government of Bangladesh”.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. In the said Act, reference to “Pakistan” or “Province” shall, except where the reference occurs in any citation or description of any law and except where the context otherwise requires, be construed as reference to “Bangladesh”.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. In the said Act, reference to “Central Legislature” or “Provincial Legislature” shall, except where the context otherwise requires, be construed as reference to “Legislature of Bangladesh”.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. In the said Act, reference to “State Bank of Pakistan” shall, except where the context otherwise requires, be construed as reference to “Bangladesh Bank”.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. In the said Act, reference to “Federation” shall, except where the context otherwise requires, be construed as reference to, “People's Republic of Bangladesh”.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
378	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH (ADAPTATION OF UNIVERSITY LAWS) ORDINANCE 1972 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>THE </strong><strong>BANGLADESH</strong><strong> (ADAPTATION OF UNIVERSITY LAWS) ORDINANCE 1972 </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(BANGLADESH ORDINANCE NO. I OF 1972).[5th January, 1972] An Ordinance to adapt the university laws in Bangladesh. WHEREAS it is expedient to adapt the university laws in Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Declaration of Independence of Bangladesh and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Acting President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> Commencement </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Ordinance may be called the Bangladesh (Adaptation of University Laws) Ordinance 1972.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It shall come into force at once and shall be deemed to have taken effect on the 16th day of December, 1971.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Adaptation of University laws</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. (1) As from the 16th day of December, 1971, the university laws mentioned in sub-section (2) shall, until repealed or altered or amended by the Legislature of Bangladesh or any other competent authority, be subject to the adaptations specified in that sub-section.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">E. P. Ord. No. XXIII of 1961.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">E. P. Ord. No. XXVIII of 1961</p><p style="text-align: justify;">E. P. Ord. No. XXXVI of 1961.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">E. P. Ord. No. IX of 1966.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">E. P. Ord. No. XXI of 1970 (2) In the Rajshahi University Ordinance, 1961, the Dacca University Ordinance, 1961, the East Pakistan Agricultural University Ordinance, 1961, the East Pakistan Engineering and Technological University Ordinance, 1961, the Chittagong University Ordinance, 1966, and the Jahangirnagar Muslim University Ordinance, 1970, references to “Governor”, “East Pakistan” and “Provincial Government” shall, except where the reference occurs in  the title or preamble or any citation or description of the Ordinance and except where the context otherwise requires, be construed as references to “President”, “Bangladesh” and “Government of Bangladesh” respectively</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
379	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH (ADMINISTRATION OF BANKS) ORDER 1971</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>THE </strong><strong>BANGLADESH</strong><strong> (ADMINISTRATION OF BANKS) ORDER, 1971 </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ACTING PRESIDENT’S ORDER NO. 3 OF 1971).[29th December, 1971]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to make provisions for the administration of Banks with head offices in Pakistan, formerly known as West Pakistan.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of Independence of Bangladesh and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Acting President is pleased to make the following Order:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Order may be called the Bangladesh (Administration of Banks) Order 1971.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It shall come into force at once.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. (1) Where any Bank having offices and branches in Bangladesh has its head office in Pakistan, formerly known as West Pakistan, the Government of Bangladesh may, notwithstanding anything contained in any law for the time being in force or in any instrument or document relating to the incorporation or registration of the Bank, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint an Administrator for the management and control of the affairs of the Bank in Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Where an Administrator is appointed for any Bank under clause (1), the Board of Directors of the Bank shall cease to function in respect of the Bank in Bangladesh and all the powers and duties of the Board of Directors or, as the case may be, Local Board of the Bank of Bangladesh shall vest in the Administrator.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Administrator shall hold office for such period and on such terms and conditions as the Government of Bangladesh may specify.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) In addition to the powers and duties of the Board of Directors, an Administrator shall also have the powers and duties of the Chief Executive of the Bank in Bangladesh and shall be wholly responsible for the management of its affairs in Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. An Administrator shall exercise his powers and discharge his duties under the direct supervision and control of the Government of Bangladesh and shall submit to the Government of Bangladesh such statements and furnish such information as the Government of Bangladesh may direct or require from time to time.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. This Order shall also apply to a Bank in Bangladesh which is a subsidiary to a Bank mentioned in clause (1) of article 2.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. No action taken under this Order shall be called in question by or before any Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
380	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH (ADMINISTRATION OF FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS) ORDER 1972 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>THE </strong><strong>BANGLADESH</strong><strong> (ADMINISTRATION OF FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS) ORDER 1972 </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ACTING PRESIDENT'S ORDER NO. 3 OF 1972).[7th January 1972]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to make provisions for the management and administration of certain financial institutions in Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of Independence of Bangladesh, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Acting President is pleased to make the following Order:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Order may be called the Bangladesh (Administration of Financial Institutions) Order 1972.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force at once.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Order, “financial institutions” means-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the House Building Finance Corporation established under the House Building Finance Corporation Act, 1952 (Act No. XVIII of 1952);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1[ * * *]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the Investment Corporation of Pakistan established under the Investment Corporation of Pakistan Ordinance, 1966 (Ordinance No. IV of 1966);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        the Equity Participation Fund established under the Equity Participation Fund Ordinance, 1970 (Ordinance No. I of 1970).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in any of laws mentioned in Article 2, or in any other law for the time being in force, the Government of Bangladesh may, if it deems fit in the national interest, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint an Administrator for the management and administration of the affairs of a financial institution in Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Where an Administrator is appointed for a financial institution under clause (1), the Board of Directors, the Managing Director and the Executive Committee, if any, of the institution shall cease to function in respect of the affairs of the institution in Bangladesh and all the powers and duties of such Board of Directors, Managing Director and Executive Committee shall vest in the Administrator.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Administrator shall be the Chief Executive of the financial institution for which he is appointed and shall hold office for such period and on such terms and conditions as the Government of Bangladesh may determine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. Subject to the direction and control of the Government of Bangladesh the Administrator shall exercise his powers and perform his duties, as far as practicable, in accordance with the provisions of the law under which the financial institution concerned is established and the rules and regulations made thereunder.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. The Administrator shall submit such statements and furnish such information as the Government of Bangladesh may direct or require from time to time.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. No action taken under this Order shall be called in question by or before any Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. For the purpose of this Order, in all the laws mentioned in Article 2 and in all rules and regulations made thereunder, references to Central Government, Pakistan and East Pakistan shall, except where the context otherwise requires, be construed as references to the Government of Bangladesh and Bangladesh respectively.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Clause (b) was omitted by section 3 of the Refugees Rehabilitation Finance Corporation (Repeal) Act, 1974 (Act No. XVI of 1974)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
381	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">   THE BANGLADESH BANK (DEMONETISATION OF CURRENCY NOTES) ORDER, 1972 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>THE BANGLADESH BANK (DEMONETISATION OF CURRENCY NOTES) ORDER, 1972 </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(PRESIDENT'S ORDER NO. 20 OF 1972).[4th March, 1972]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS large quantity of currency notes has been illegally removed by Pakistan occupation forces, from the Government Treasuries, former State Bank of Pakistan and from offices and branches of banks located in Bangladesh before their surrender to the Allied Armed Forces;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">AND WHEREAS such illegally acquired currency notes are likely to have been passed on by them to be used for activities prejudicial to the National Economy;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">AND WHEREAS it is expedient to withdraw from circulation currency notes of certain denomination;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of Independence of Bangladesh, 1971, read with the Provisional Constitution of Bangladesh Order, 1972, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Order:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Order shall come into force at once and shall take effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith in any other law for the time being in force.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. All Pakistan currency notes of Rs. 50 denomination, which were made legal tender in Bangladesh in pursuance of Bangladesh Bank (Temporary) Order, 1971, dated the 25th December 1971, made and promulgated by the Acting President of the People's Republic of Bangladesh, shall on the 5th March, 1972, cease to be legal tender within the meaning of the State Bank of Pakistan Act, 1956 (XXXIII of 1956) as adapted in Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. All holders of currency notes specified in paragraph 2 shall surrender them to any of the branches of the scheduled banks or to any Head Post Office and Departmental Sub-Post Office in Bangladesh on the following dates:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Monday the 6th  March, 1972</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Tuesday the 7th  March, 1972</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Wednesday the 8th  March, 1972</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">whereafter these currency notes shall not be accepted.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. Branches of the scheduled banks and collecting agencies mentioned in paragraph 3 shall record the name and address of the person surrendering them and value of such currency notes and shall give a proper receipt to the person surrendering them.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) The Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh shall set up a committee or committees as it may deem fit and such committee or committees shall decide—</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        which of the currency notes surrendered under paragraph 3 were illegally acquired or illegally removed from the former State Bank of Pakistan or any of its branches or from any office or branch of any other bank or any Government Treasury; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        whether any person surrendering any such currency notes has evaded any tax payable to the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) A committee or committees so appointed may frame rules and regulations or may issue such directives as it may deem necessary for the performance of its function.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The committee may exempt tenders of demonetised notes of any specific amount or tenders made by any category of persons exempt from scrutiny.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The decision of a committee under sub-paragraphs (1), (2) and (3) shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. A person who has surrendered any currency notes under paragraph 3 shall on production of the receipt issued to him under paragraph 4, be entitled to receive, on such dates as may be notified by the Bangladesh Bank in the official Gazette or otherwise, the amount equivalent to the value of the currency notes so surrendered by him from such bank or agency as may be mentioned in the notification, provided -</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the currency notes surrendered by him have not been found by the committee to have been illegally acquired or illegally removed from any branches of the former State Bank of Pakistan or from any office or branch of any other bank or from any Government Treasury; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) such person has been found by the committee not to have evaded any tax payable to the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. The Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh and/or Bangladesh Bank, for the purpose of this Order, may make such rules or issue such directives to such person or authority as it may deem necessary, and it would be mandatory for such persons or authority to execute such rules or directives as may be issued by the Government or Bangladesh Bank under this clause.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. No provision of this Order, nor any action taken thereunder, shall be called in question by or before any court of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. Whoever fails to take any action required of him by this Order or by any rule made or direction issued under paragraph 7 or furnishes false information to the person receiving the surrendered currency notes or to the committee set up under paragraph 5 of this Order shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment which may extend to three years' or with fine or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1[ 10. Notwithstanding anything contained in this Order or any other Order or Law in force, the Bangladesh Bank may with the approval of the Government pay exchange value of demonetised Pakistani Currency Notes of Rs. 50 denomination, which were held by Courts or Customs Authorities (including those of Indian Courts and Customs Authorities seized between the 26th of March, 1971 and 16th December, 1971) as alamats or exhibit or as pieces of evidence and were released after the 8th of March, 1972, subject to production of evidence to the satisfaction of the authorities concerned.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Article 10 was inserted by Article 2 of the Bangladesh Bank (Demonetisation of Currency Notes) (Amendment) Order, 1972 (President's Order No. 119 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p> </div></div>
382	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH BANK ORDER, 1972 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>THE BANGLADESH BANK ORDER, 1972 </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(PRESIDENT'S ORDER NO. 127 OF 1972).[31st October, 1972]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1[ WHEREAS, it is necessary to establish a central bank in Bangladesh to manage the monetary and credit system of Bangladesh with a view to stabilising domestic monetary value and maintaining a competitive external par value of the Bangladesh Taka towards fostering growth and development of country’s productive resources in the best national interest;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of Independence of Bangladesh, read with the Provisional Constitution of Bangladesh Order, 1972, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make the following Order:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>CHAPTER I</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>PRELIMINARY</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Order may be called the Bangladesh Bank Order, 1972.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force at once and shall be deemed to have taken effect on the 16th day of December, 1971.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Order, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “appointed day” means the 16th day of December, 1971;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “approved foreign exchange” means currencies declared as such by any notification under Article 18;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “Bank” means the Bangladesh Bank;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2[ (cc) “banking company” means "?????? ????????" defined in ??? (?) of ???? ? of ?????? ???????? ???, ???? (???? ???? ?? ?? ???);]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        “Bank Notes” means 3[ notes and coins] made and issued by the Bank in accordance with Article 23;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4[ (dd) “bank rate” means the standard rate made public by the Bangladesh Bank under Article 21;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        “Board” means the Board of Directors of the Bank;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5[ (ee) “coin” means, except for the purpose of clause (d) above, a coin issued under the provisions of the Bangladesh Coinage Order, 1972 (P.O. No. 83 of 1972);] (f)         “Co-operative Bank” means any co-operative society or co-operative bank including the apex co-operative bank registered under 6[ ????? ????? ???, ???? (???? ???? ?? ?? ???)], or any other law for the time being in force relating to co-operative societies, one objectives of which is to provide financial accommodation to its members;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        “Director” means a Director of the Bank;           7[ (gg) “financial institution” means "?????? ??????????" defined in ??? (?) of ???? ? of ?????? ?????????? ???, ???? (???? ???? ?? ?? ???);]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        “Governor” and “Deputy Governor” means respectively the Governor and Deputy Governor of the Bank;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         “Government” means the Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j)         “Scheduled Bank” means a bank for the time being included in the list of banks maintained under sub-clause (a) of clause (2) of Article 37;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k)        “State Bank” means the State Bank of Pakistan constituted under the State Bank of Pakistan Act, 1956;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8[ (l)     “Taka Coin” means one Taka coin and one Taka note and two Taka note coin and two Taka note which are legal tender in Bangladesh.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER II</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">ESTABLISHMENT, INCORPORATION, CAPITAL AND MANAGEMENT</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) There shall be a bank to be called the Bangladesh Bank for the purposes of carrying on the business of central banking and it shall be deemed to have been established on the appointed day.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Bank shall be a body corporate by the name of the Bangladesh Bank, having perpetual succession and a common seal, and shall by the said name sue and be sued.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) The capital of the Bank shall be Taka three crores.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The entire capital of the Bank shall stand vested in, and allotted to, the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The capital of the Bank may, subject to the approval of the Government, be increased by a resolution of the Board, and any capital so increased shall be subscribed for by the Government in such form and manner as may be determined by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) On the appointed day all the shares of the State Bank held in Bangladesh which have not already vested in the Government by or under any other law for the time being in force, shall, by virtue of this Order, be deemed to have been vested in, and allotted to, the Government free from any trust, mortgage, charge, lien, interest, or other encumbrance whatsoever.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The Government shall pay such compensation in respect of the shares vested in the Government under clause (4) as may be determined by it and such compensation shall be distributed among the share-holders of the State Bank in Bangladesh in the manner as may be determined by the Government:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the total compensation payable under this clause shall not exceed the total paid up value of the shares held by the share-holders, among whom such compensation is to be distributed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) On the appointed day the entire undertaking of the State Bank in and in relation to Bangladesh shall be deemed to have been transferred to, and vested in, the Bank.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The undertaking of the State Bank so transferred and vested shall be deemed to include all assets, rights, powers, authorities and privileges and all property, movable and immovable, including all lands, buildings, cash balances, reserve funds, investments, and debts or actionable claims, any security or negotiable instrument, and all other rights and interests in, or arising out of, such property as were immediately before the appointed day in the ownership, possession, power or control of the State Bank in relation to, or for the purposes of, the undertaking of the State Bank in or in relation to Bangladesh whether such property is situated within or without Bangladesh, and all books of account, registers, records and all other documents of whatever nature relating thereto and shall also be deemed to include all borrowings, liabilities and obligations of whatever kind of the State Bank in relation to the undertaking within the territory of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Subject to the provisions of this Order all contracts, deeds, bonds, agreements, powers of attorney, grants of legal representation and other instruments of whatever nature subsisting or having effect immediately before the appointed day and to which the State Bank is a party or which are in favour of the State Bank shall-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        if they are exclusively for the purposes or for the business of the undertaking of the State Bank in Bangladesh; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        if they are partly for the purposes in sub-clause (a) and partly for any other purpose to the extent and subject to such conditions and limitation, as the Government may determine, be of as full force and effect against or in favour of the Bank and may be enforced or acted upon as fully and effectively as if in place of the State Bank, the Bank has been a party thereto or as if they had been issued in favour of the Bank.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (1) All suits, appeals, or other legal proceedings of whatever nature pending on the appointed day by or against the State Bank in relation to its undertaking which has vested in the Bank under Article 5, shall be deemed to be suits, appeals and other legal proceedings pending by or against the Bank and may be continued and enforced by or against the Bank.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, where any proceeding for the winding up of a banking company under the Banking Companies Ordinance, 1962, is pending before the High Court of Bangladesh immediately before the appointed day in which the State Bank was appointed as Official Liquidator, the Bank shall be substituted in place of the State Bank as the Official Liquidator and shall be deemed always to have been so substituted.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. Subject to the provisions of this Order and any other law for the time being in force, any person being a citizen of Bangladesh who, immediately before the appointed day, was an employee of the State Bank shall, as from that day, continue to be an employee of the Bank on the same terms and conditions as were applicable to him immediately before that day.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7A</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9[ 7A. The main functions of the Bank shall be:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) to formulate and implement monetary policy;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) to formulate and implement intervention policies in the foreign exchange market;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) to give advice to the Government on the interaction of monetary policy with fiscal and exchange rate policy, on the impact of various policy measures on the economy and to propose legislative measures it considers necessary or appropriate to attain its objectives and perform its functions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) to hold and manage the official foreign reserves of Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) to promote, regulate and ensure a secure and efficient payment system, including the issue of bank notes;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) to regulate and supervise banking companies and financial institutions.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) The Head Office of the Bank shall be at Dacca.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10[ (2) The Bank shall have offices at Dhaka, Chittagong, Khulna, Bogra, Rajshahi, Sylhet, Barisal, Rangpur and may establish other offices, branches and agencies in Bangladesh or in consultation with the Government anywhere outside Bangladesh.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. 11[ * * *]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) 12[ The general superintendence] and direction of the affairs and business of the Bank shall be entrusted to a Board of Directors which may exercise all the powers and do all acts and things that may be exercised or done by the Bank 13[ :</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that until the first Board is constituted, the Governor may exercise all powers and do all acts and things as are required to be exercised or done by the Board.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14[ (3) The Board shall consist of-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the Governor;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        a Deputy Governors, to be nominated by the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)         15[ four Directors who will not be Government officials] to be nominated by the Government from amongst persons who, in the opinion of the Government, have had experience and shown capacity in the field of banking, trade, commerce, industry or agriculture.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) three Government Officials to be nominated by the Government.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9A</p><p style="text-align: justify;">16[ 9A. (1) There shall be a Council for the co-ordination of fiscal, monetary and exchange rate policies, hereinafter called the Co-ordination Council, consisting of-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) Minister for Finance  ..........  Chairman.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) Minister for Commerce        ..........  Member.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii) Governor, Bangladesh Bank            ..........  Member.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iv) Secretary, Finance Division ..........  Member.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(v) Secretary, Internal Resources Division         ..........  Member.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(vi)       Member (Programming), Planning Commission  ..........  Member.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Co-ordination Council shall-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) co-ordinate the macro-economic framework including fiscal, monetary and exchange rate strategies and policies;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) ensure consistency among macro-economic targets of growth, inflation and fiscal, monetary and external accounts;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) meet for the purposes of clauses (a) and (b) before the finalization of the budget to determine the extent of public sector borrowing taking into account credit requirements of the private sector, monetary expansion based on projected growth, price inflation, and net foreign assets of the banking system;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) meet at least on a quarterly basis to review the consistency of macro-economic policies and to revise limits and targets set at the time of the formulation of the budget, keeping in view the latest developments in the economy;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) consider limits of the government borrowing as revised from time to time in the meetings to be held before and after passage of the annual budget.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Bangladesh Bank shall ensure that the macro-economic framework as co-ordinated by the Co-ordination Council is reflected in the policies of the Bangladesh Bank.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Bangladesh Bank shall place before the Co-ordination Council-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) relevant data relating to monetary expansion and Government borrowing from the banking system, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the assessment of the Bangladesh Bank regarding the impact of economic policies of the government on monetary aggregates and balance of payments.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The Ministry of Finance shall, from time to time, bring to the notice of the Co-ordination Council the impact of tax, budget and debt management policies on overall macro-economic situation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) The Ministry of Commerce shall from time to time, bring to the notice of the Co-ordination Council the impact of trade and tariff policies on overall macro-economic situation.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. (1) The Governor of the Bank shall be the Chief Executive Officer and shall, on behalf of the Board, direct and control the whole affairs of the Bank.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In the matters not specifically required by this Order or by regulations made thereunder, to be done by the Board, the Government shall have powers of general superintendence and directions of the affairs and business of the Bank and may exercise all powers and do all acts and things which may be exercised or done by the Bank.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Governor shall be appointed 17[ by the Government] on such salary and terms and conditions as may be determined by the Government except that neither the salary of the Governor nor his other terms and conditions of service shall be varied to his disadvantage after his appointment.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) One or more Deputy Governors shall be appointed 18[ by the Government] on such salary and on such terms and conditions as the Government may determine except that neither the salary of a Deputy Governor nor his other terms and conditions shall be varied to his disadvantage after his appointment.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">19[ (5) The Governor shall hold office for a period of four years and shall be eligible for re-appointment:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Governor shall not hold office if he attains the age of sixty five years.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) The Governor and a Deputy Governor shall devote their whole time to the affairs of the Bank.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">20[ (7) The Government may require a Deputy Governor to hold an office other than in the Bank, in which event the Deputy Governor shall vacate his office, and the period during which he holds the other office shall not count towards his tenure of office as Deputy Governor.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(8) The Governor, or a Deputy Governor, as the case may be, in addition to his duties as the Governor or a Deputy Governor, be entrusted by an order of the Government with such duties for such period as may be specified in the order.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(9) No person shall hold office as 21[ Governor or Deputy Governor] 22[ * * *]:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">23[ (a)  who is a member of the Legislature or a local Government;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        who is employed in any capacity in the public service of Bangladesh or holds any office or position for which any salary or other remuneration is payable out of public funds;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        who is a Director, officer or employee of any other 24[ banking company or financial institution] or of any other business concern:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that nothing in this sub-clause shall apply where the 25[ Governor or Deputy Governor] 26[ * * *] is entrusted with additional duties under clause (8);</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">27[ (d) who has defaulted in payment of dues of the government or of any banking company or any financial institutions;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">28[ (e) who is, or at any time has been, adjudicated an insolvent or had suspended payment or has compounded with his creditors;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) who is found lunatic or becomes of unsound mind;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) who has been convicted of an offence involving moral turpitude or has been sentenced by a court for a term of imprisonment exceeding one year.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(10) The Government may grant leave to the Governor and a Deputy Governor for such period and on such terms and conditions as may be specified by the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(11) Where the Governor 29[ * * *] during his term of office is incapacitated or is absent on deputation, leave or otherwise, the Government may appoint any person qualified under clause (9) but who may not be qualified under sub-clause (b) of that clause to act for the time being as the Governor 30[ * * *] in his place.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) Meetings of the Board shall be convened by the Governor at least six times in each year and at least once in each quarter.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Any three Directors may require the Governor to convene a meeting of the Board at any time and the Governor shall forthwith convene a meeting accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">31[ (3) The Governor or, if for any reason he is unable to attend, the Deputy Governor nominated under sub-clause (b) of clause (3) of Article 9, shall preside at meetings of the Board and in the event of any equality of votes, shall have a second or casting vote. In case the Deputy Governor is also unable to attend for any reason, any other Director, authorised by the Governor, shall preside over the meeting of the Board and shall have a second or casting vote.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) No act or proceedings of the Board shall be questioned on the ground merely of the existence of any vacancy in, or any defect in the constitution of, the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. 32[ (1) There shall be an Executive Committee consisting of-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the Governor;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the Director nominated under sub-clause (b) of clause (3) of Article 9;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        one Director elected by the Board from amongst the Directors nominated under sub-clause (c) of clause (3) of Article 9; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        one Director appointed by the Government from amongst the Directors nominated under sub-clause (d) of clause (3) of Article 9.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">33[ * * *]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Except when the Board is in session, the Executive Committee shall deal with and decide any matter within the competence of the Board and shall keep minutes of its proceedings, which shall be submitted to the Board for information at its next meeting.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. (1) No person shall be or shall continue to be a Director-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">34[ (a)  who is a Member of the Legislature or a local Government; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) who has defaulted in payment of dues of the Government or of any banking company or any financial institution; or]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        who is, or at any time has been, adjudicated an insolvent or has suspended payment or has compounded with his creditors; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        who is found lunatic or becomes of unsound mind; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        who is an officer or employee of any 35[ banking company] or any financial institution; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         who is a Director of 36[ any banking company or financial institution], but he shall not be disqualified or cease to be a Director if he is a Director of a bank which is a society registered under the 37[ ????? ????? ???, ???? (???? ???? ?? ?? ???)] or any other law for the time being in force relating to co-operative societies; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) who absents himself from three consecutive meetings of the Board, without leave from the Board; 38[ or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) who has been convicted of an offence involving moral turpitude or has been sentenced by a court for a term of imprisonment exceeding one year.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Nothing in sub-clause (b) of clause (1) of this Article shall apply to the Government official nominated as Director under sub-clause 39[ (d)] of clause (3) of Article 9.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14</p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. (1) The Directors nominated under sub-clause 40[ (c)] of clause (3) of Article 9 shall hold office for three years.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) A Director nominated under sub-clause 41[ (d)] of clause (3) of Article 9 shall hold office at the pleasure of the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Directors shall on the expiry of their term of office be eligible for renomination.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">15</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. (1) The Government may remove from office-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the Governor or 42[ a Deputy Governor] if he becomes permanently incapable of performing his duties or subject to any of the disqualifications specified in clause (9) of Article 10 or has done any act which is a breach of the trust reposed in him, or if his continuance in office is regarded as manifestly opposed to the interests of the Bank; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        any Director.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) (a) The Governor, 43[ a Deputy Governor] or a Director may resign his office by statement to that effect in writing signed by him and addressed to the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        A statement of resignation by 44[ a Deputy Governor] or 45[ a Director] shall be addressed as above through the Governor;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        On the acceptance of such a resignation by the Government, the office shall become vacant;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Any Director vacating office under this Article shall not be eligible to become a Director until the expiry of the term of office for which he was nominated; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) In the event of a vacancy occurring, the Government shall fill the vacancy by nominating another Director.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER III</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">BUSINESS AND FUNCTIONS OF THE BANK</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16</p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. The Bank is authorised to carry on and transact the several kinds of business hereinafter specified, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">46[ (1) The accepting of money on deposit from and the collection of money for the Government, foreign Governments, domestic and foreign banks, domestic and foreign financial institutions and local authorities with or without interest.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">47[ * * *]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) (a)  The purchase, sale and rediscount of bills of exchange and promissory notes drawn on and payable in Bangladesh and arising out of bona fide commercial or trade transactions bearing two or more good signatures one of which shall be that of a scheduled bank, and maturing within one hundred eighty days, from the date of such purchase or rediscount, exclusive of days of grace;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        The purchase, sale and rediscount of bills of exchange and promissory notes, drawn on and payable in Bangladesh and bearing two or more good signatures one of which shall be that of a scheduled bank or the apex co-operative bank and drawn or issued for the purpose of financing seasonal agricultural operations or the marketing of crops, and maturing within fifteen months from the date of such purchase or rediscount exclusive of days of grace;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Explanation - For the purpose of this sub-clause-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">48[ (i)   The expression ‘agricultural operations' include cultivation of crops, plantation, agricultural machineries and implements, fertilizers and pesticides, fishing, pisciculture, animal husbandry, forestry, horticulture and allied activities;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        “crops” include products of agricultural operations;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii)       the expression “marketing of crops” includes the processing of crops prior to marketing by agricultural producers or any organisation of such producers;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        The purchase, sale and rediscount of bills of exchange and promissory notes drawn on and payable in Bangladesh and bearing two or more good signatures, one of which shall be that of the apex co-operative bank or a financial corporation and drawn or issued for the purpose of financing the production or marketing activities of cottage and small scale industries approved by the Bank and maturing within eighteen months from the date of such purchase or rediscount, exclusive of days of grace:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the payment of the principal and interest of such bills of exchange or promissory notes is guaranteed by the Government to the satisfaction of the Bank.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        The making to a corporation declared eligible by the Government in consultation with the Bank of loans and advances-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         repayable on demand or on the expiry of fixed periods not exceeding ninety days from the date of such loan or advance, against securities of the Government; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        repayable on the expiry of fixed periods not exceeding eighteen months from the date of such loan or advance, against securities of the Government of any maturity, or against bonds and debentures issued by the Corporation to which the loan or advance is made, and guaranteed by the Government and maturing within a period not exceeding eighteen months from the date of such loan or advance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        The purchase, sale and rediscount of bills of exchange and promissory notes drawn on and payable in Bangladesh and bearing the signature of a scheduled bank, and issued or drawn for the purpose of holding or trading in securities of the Government and maturing within ninety days from the date of such purchase or rediscount, exclusive of days of grace;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         The purchase, sale and rediscount of bills of exchange and promissory notes drawn on and payable in Bangladesh and bearing two or more good signatures one of which shall be that of a scheduled bank or the apex co-operative Bank or any corporation approved by the Government and having as one of its objects the making of loans and advances in cash or kind, drawn and issued for financing the development of agriculture, or of agricultural or animal produce or the needs of industry, having maturities not exceeding ten years from the date of such purchase or rediscount:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Bank may from time to time issue to a corporation which may have dealings with the Bank under this sub-clause any directions which can by issued to a banking company under the 49[ ?????? ???????? ???, ???? (???? ???? ?? ?? ???)], and in the event of anybody, while carrying out any direction hereunder, either wilfully making a false statement or wilfully omitting to make material statement shall be punishable under 50[ sub-section (2) of section 109 of the said Act of 1991], and in the event of any contravention or default in compliance with any direction, any Director or Officer who is knowingly a party to the contravention or default shall be punishable under 51[ sub-section (7) of section of the said section], and the provisions of 52[ section 111 of the said Act] shall apply to such proceedings as if such corporation were a banking company;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        The purchase, sale and rediscount of such Government guaranteed debentures issued by a public company or corporation established by or under any law for the time being in force as the Bank may from time to time approve in this behalf;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        To guarantee, to the extent the Bank deems fit, issue of loans and debentures by the scheduled banks or financial institutions to rural credit institutions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         To guarantee funds of scheduled banks in agricultural credit operations to the extent the bank deems fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) (a)  The purchase and sale of approved foreign exchange;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        The purchase, sale and rediscount of bills of exchange including treasury bills drawn in or on any place in countries whose currency has been declared as approved foreign exchange and maturing within one hundred and eighty days from the date of purchase:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no such purchase, sale or rediscount shall be made in Bangladesh except with a scheduled bank;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        The keeping of balances with banks in countries whose currency has been declared as approved foreign exchange;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">53[ (d) subject to the approval of the Board the placing of balances abroad with asset management companies of global standing and reputation for investment in countries whose currencies have been declared as approved foreign exchange:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the placement under this clause shall not exceed 25 percent of the balance kept abroad.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4)        The making to local Authorities, scheduled banks or co-operative banks of advances and loans repayable on demand or on the expiry of fixed periods not exceeding ninety days against the security of-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) stocks, funds and securities, other than immovable property, in which a trustee is authorised to invest trust money by any law for the time being in force in Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) gold or silver or documents of title to the same;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) such bills of exchange and promissory notes as are eligible for purchase or rediscount by the bank; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) promissory notes of any scheduled bank supported by documents of title relating to goods, such documents having been transferred, assigned or pledged to any such bank as security, for a cash credit or overdraft granted for bona fide commercial or trade transactions or for the purpose of financing seasonal agricultural operations or the marketing of crops;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5)        The making of loans and advances out of the Rural Credit Fund established under Article 60 for the purposes specified therein;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6)        The making of loans and advances out of the Agricultural Credit Stabilisation Fund established under Article 61 for the purposes specified therein;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(7)        The making of loans and advances out of the Industrial Credit Fund established under Article 62 for the purposes specified therein;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(8)        The making of loans and advances out of the Export Credit Fund established under Article 63 for the purposes specified therein;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(9)        The making to the Government of advances repayable in each case not later than three months from the date of the making of the advance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(10) The making to institutions or banks, specially established for the purpose of promoting agricultural or industrial development in the country or co-operative banks of advances and loans for such amounts and on such terms and conditions as the Board may decide from time to time;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(11) The purchase holding and sale of shares and debentures of any company or corporation or institution as may be decided in consultation with the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(12) The issue and purchase of telegraphic transfers, demand drafts and other kinds of remittances made payable at its own branches, offices or agencies;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(13) The drawing, accepting, making and issue, on its own account or on account of the Government, as the case may be, of any bill of exchange, hundi, promissory note or engagement for the payment within or without Bangladesh, of Bangladesh or foreign currency payable to bearer or to a banker on demand; but no such business shall be carried on or transacted without the previous approval of the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">54[ (13A) The issue of its own negotiable securities on such rate of interest as the Bank may decide;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(14) (a) Subject to sub-clause (b) the purchases and sale of securities of countries whose currency has been declared as approved foreign exchange with an unexpired currency of not more than ten years;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) The restrictions relating to maturity shall not apply to securities held by the Bank on the date on which this Order comes into force or any securities that may be received as assets including those transferred to and vested in the Bank under Article 5;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(15) (a) The purchase and sale of securities of the Government, or of such securities of a Local Authority as may be specified in this behalf by the Government by notification in the official Gazette on the recommendation of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        Securities, Debentures and Shares fully guaranteed as to principal and interest by the Government shall be deemed for the purpose of this clause to be securities of the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        The amount of such securities held at any time in the Banking Department shall be so regulated that the total value of such securities shall not exceed the aggregate amount of the capital of the Bank, the Reserve Fund and four-fifths of the Liabilities of the Banking Department in respect of deposits;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(16) The custody of monies, securities and other articles of value and the collection of the proceeds, whether principal, interest or dividends of any such securities;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(17) The sale and realisation of all property, whether movable or immovable which may in any way come into the possession of the Bank in satisfaction, or part satisfaction of any of its claims;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(18) The acting as agent to the Government, or any Local Authority in the transaction of any of the following kinds of business, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the purchase and sale of gold or silver or approved foreign exchange;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the purchase, sale, transfer and custody of bills of exchange, securities or shares in any company;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the collection of the proceeds, whether principal, interest or dividends, or any securities or shares;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        the remittance of such proceeds at the risk of the principal, by bills of exchange payable either in Bangladesh or elsewhere;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        and the management of public debt;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(19) The purchase and sale of gold coin and gold or silver bullion;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(20) The opening of an account with or the making of any agency arrangement with, and the acting as agent or correspondent of a bank incorporated in any country outside Bangladesh or the principal currency authority of any country under the law for the time being in force in that country or any international or regional bank formed by such principal currency authorities, and the investing of the funds of the Bank in the shares and securities of any such international or regional bank;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">55[ (21) (a) Subject to sub-clauses (b) and (c), the borrowing of money for the purpose of business of the Bank and the giving of security for money so borrowed;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        No money shall be borrowed under this clause from any person in Bangladesh other than a scheduled bank for a period exceeding three months and an amount not at any time exceeding the amount of the capital of the Bank;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        No money shall be borrowed under this clause from any foreign national in or outside Bangladesh other than foreign and international banks, companies, institutions or concerns;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(22) The making and issue of bank notes subject to the provisions of this Order;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(23) The performance of the functions of the Bank under the International Financial Organisations Order, 1972;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(24) Establish credits and give guarantees; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align:
